editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Tottenham court. A pleasant comedy: acted in the year mdcxxxiii. At the private house in salisbury-court.
At London, printed by Richard Ow●●●n, for Charles green; and are to be sold at the sign of the white lion, in p à 〈◊〉 Church-yard.

div.head: To the worshipful William mills, esquire.
div.p:
Though I know your affection to things of this kind is not such, that you covet men's notice of it, I am bold to prefix your name to this, as a public declaration of the gratitude I owe you. If you vouchsafe the reading of it, you will find (After the light title) a light subject, more gravely dressed then the vulgar perhaps expected: who please their senses oftener with shows, than their intellects
with the true moral end of plays, instruction. That you should authorise it after the stages trial was not my intention (For you are none of those that glory to be thought judicious this way, your studies and employments being more high and serious) but that in your acceptance of it, you would show yourself pleased with such acknowledgements as can be rendered by

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: You're welcome gentlemen to Tot'nam-court,
Where you (Perhaps) expect some lusty sport;
Such as rude custom doth beget in may,
When straggling numbers court that jovial day
With early riot. No such thing must be
The subject of our easy comedy.
What then! A humorous, fiery, red-faced host,
That will discourse his guest into more cost
Then's cheer is worth: and lies with so much credit,
As if 'twere truth's authority, he said it,
Nor this! The author surely then intends
Some gown-man of the town, that daily spends
A thrifty penny, to preserve his lungs,
For a full voice 'Midst the contentious throngs.
But here is no such satire: nor is't fit
Abuse should be the exercise of wit.
To feast your sense and minds for cakes and ale,
New, and not staled with handling, here's a tale
Dressed up of a fair milkmaid; whose chaste theme
Shall close your stomachs up instead of cream.
Cookery and wit are like: the self same meat
Delights one's taste, another cannot eat.
So 'tis in fancy's work: this loves a jest;
That language; matter pleaseth tother best.
Our play's not larded with great store of these:
And how the relish of their salt will please
'Tis doubtful. Yet we are the less afraid;
Because your reckoning is beforehand paid.

div.head: The persons.

list.item: Her uncle. An angry country gentleman.
Ciceley. Sister to Worthgood, but unknown.
Stitchwell. A tailor of the strand.
James. A wild young gentleman of the inns of court.
Sam. A fine gentleman of the inns of court, and brother to Bellamy.

div.p: The Scene, Tottenham-court, and the fields about is.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Worthgood and Bellamy, as travailing together before day.

sp.speaker: Worthgood.
sp.l: Come, my delight; let not such painted griefs
Press down thy soul: the darkness but presents
Shadows of fear, which should secure us best from danger of pursuit.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Would it were day:
My apprehension is so full of horror,
I think each sound the air's light motion
Makes in these thickets, is my uncle's voice,
Threatening our ruins.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Let his rage persist
To enterprise a vengeance; we'll prevent it.
Wrapped in the arms of night (That favours lovers)
We hitherto have scaped his eager search,
And are arrived near London. Sure I hear
The bridge's cataracts, and such like murmurs
As night and sleep yield from a populous number.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: But when will it be day? the light hath comfort.
〈…〉 senses being lost,
The l●st are less delighted.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Th'early cock
Hath sung his summons to the day's approach:
'Twill instantly appear. Why, startled Bellamy!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Did no amazing sounds arrive your ear?
Pray listen.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Come, come; 'tis thy fear suggests
Illusive fancies: under love's protection
We may presume of safety.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow. She startles from him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay me, 'tis sure mine uncle. Dear love. Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Astonishment hath seized my faculties.
My love, my Bellamy. Ha!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Dost thou forsake me Worthgood?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Where's my love?
Dart from thy silver crescent one fair beam
Through this black air thou governess of night,
To show me whither she is led by fear.
Thou envious darkness to assist us hither,
And now prove fatal.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Silence your noise, ye clamorous ministers
Of this injustice. Bellamy is lost;
She's lost to me. Nor her fierce uncle's rage
Who whets your eager aptness to pursue me
With threats or promises; nor his painted terrors
Of law's severity, could ever work
Upon the temper of my resolute soul,
To soften't into fear, till she was lost:Hollow within.
Not all th'illusive horrors which the night
Presents unto th'imagination
T'affright a guilty conscience, could possess me,
Whilst I possessed my love: the dismal shrieks
of fatal owls, and groans of dying mandrakes,
Whilst her soft palm warmed mine, were music to me,
And were this hand but once more clasped in hers,
This should resist th'assault, inspired by love
With more than humane vigour.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Their light appears. No safety doth consist
In passion or complaints. Night, let thine arms
Again receive me; and if no kind minister
Of better fate guide me to Bellamy;
Be thou eternal.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

div.head: Scene. 2.
div.stage: Enter uncle, servants and tenants with lights, as pursuing them.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: Come, wing your hasts: I'll sweeten all your labours
With large rewards: do but recover them,
I'll ease your rends; exact no costly customs;
Quarrel no more about your commons title.
Good neighbours forward: london's not far off.

sp.speaker: 1 ten.
sp.p: 'Tis so far off, that I cannot see it.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.p: The day will soon discover it.

sp.speaker: 2 ten.
sp.l: That day is sure a notable informer; yet I believe
He spies more bad than he mends.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.p: Come, follow me this way.

sp.speaker: 1 ten.
sp.p: Yes, we will follow; but at some wiser distance: stay neighbour let him go. Shall we rob our carcases of sleep all night, that have been sufficiently tired with the day's toils, for his reward? what will that be you? A Christmas dinner; with a chine of his great ox that died at watering of the blain.

sp.speaker: 2 ten.
sp.l: You say well neighbour:
and a st●ale hare with a great pudding in her belly.

sp.speaker: 1 ten.
sp.p: And the discourse of his worships hunting her: how many doubles she made, and mocked his worship's hope of a better dinner so long, till he thought in his conference she was a Lancashire witch.

sp.speaker: 2 ten
sp.p: Yes neighbour, and a choler of brawn that was fattened with stale porridge.

sp.speaker: 1 ten.
sp.p: And a goose that broke her neck, creeping through the hedge into the parson's stubble.

sp.speaker: 2 ten.
sp.p: No neighbour, let the young couple go, and much joy go with them. Let us take up our rests in this thicket, or the next house; for I am as sleepy as if I had eaten a puppy.

sp.speaker: 1 ten.
sp.p: How, eat a puppy ▪

sp.speaker: 2 ten.
sp.p: Yes, a puppy; I heard our landlord's carter speak it last Whitsuntide in a play.

sp.speaker: 1 ten.
sp.p: And I am as drowsy as a constable at midnight.

sp.speaker: 2 ten.
sp.p: Why then resolved: 'twill be day presently: let's put on't the candle, and go to bed, and farewell landlord. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: The day begins to break; and trembling light
As if affrighted with this night's disaster,
Steals through the farthest air, and by degrees
Salutes my weary longings. Yet 'tis welcome,
Though it betray me to the worst of fate
Love and desire e'er suffered. O my Worthgood,
Thy presence would have checked these passions;
And shot delight through all the mists of sadness,
To guide my fear safe through the paths of danger:
But thou art lost, and all my joys are fled
Not to return without thee.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: New fears assault me. 'tis a woman's voice.
She sings; and in her music's cheerfulness
Seems to express the freedom of a heart
Not chained to any passions. Be propitious
Thou regent o'er my fate, and guide her hither
Unto my comfort.

div.head: The song within.
div.l: What a dainty life the milkmaid leads?
When over the flowery meads
She dabbles in the dew,
And sings to her cow;
And feels not the pain
Of love or disdain.
She sleeps in the night, though she toils in the day;
And merrily passeth her time away.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: What a blessed state is this? the mind's content
Sweetens all sufferings of th'afflicted sense.
Those that are bred in labour think it sport
Above the soft delights which wanton appetite
Begets for others, whom indulgent fortune
Prefers in her degrees; though equal nature
Made all alike. O, might I change my misery
For such a shape of quiet.

div.head: The fourth scene.
To her Ciceley, as going to milking.
div.l: She comes this way.
He venture to accost her.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Ha! what silken butterfly's yonder! She looks not like one that had kept herself warm all night at the brick-kils: yet silk petticoats many times are glad with worse lodging.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Good morrow maid.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Should I salute you so, 'twould bring my wit in question. Pray you what are you?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: A distressed maid.

sp.speaker: ●●ce
sp.p: A maid at your years, and so near London; where the state of one at 15. is as rate as a light wench's conversion. Never an early walking gallant to take you up this morning! The park here hath fine conveniences: or Tottenham court's close by: 'tis suspected that fine city ladies give away fine things to court lords for a country banquet there.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I cannot construe it; my innocence makes understanding useless. Good maid, wife or widow (For sure you are a woman) do a courteous office to your sex in me, and guide me to London.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: It seems you are a kind country gentlewoman, that have bestowed your maidenhead on your father's servingman, and are come up to have a citizen fodder your broken ware. The policy is grown stale: 'twould hardly take ever since the ballad cursed the carrier that brought her to town.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You're a bad woman sure: and from th'abundance of you own foul ills suspect all others.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: The to, is angry, it would fain counterfeit something: perhaps to insinuate herself, and make me her agent. But you are deceived my pretty morsel of wantonness; myself and my milkpail are both honest: I have no disguised tone of come, or three penny thrip to cloak a procuress. I am not the blade's intelligence whether Frank or Moll remove their lodgings to scape the constable's search and Bridewell. I will to my cows, and leave you to the fate of the morning: despair not of a customer; but be sure I catch you not napping; for if I do, I have less mercy than prentices at Shrovetide. I hate hedge-coupling worse than fasting at Christmas, or a Puritans long grace over short commons.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: If you are good, pray stay and comfort me.
The sense of my 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Why let but an honest 〈…〉 in Middlesex) find you not guilty of any thing that may make compassion deaf — alas, she swoons; poor gentlewoman, be comforted. Should she miscarry, I were in danger, having no witness to purge the suspicion of being her murderess.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Worthgood farewell.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Ha! what said she? Worthgood! I have heard my father often speak that name, and sigh after it. Alas, she is dead; her breath scarce moves.

div.head: The fifth scene.
To them keeper and slip.
div.p: O father, you are come in time to see me undone: I met this gentlewoman as I was going to milking, and she is fallen dead. I shall be questioned.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Why what is she?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Nay that's as hard to tell, as the success of my danger. She named one Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: That word strikes deep amazement. Is she quite dead!

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Dead as a herring sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: And are not you in a pickle Cicely? She is not dead sir; she breathes.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: She may be recovered. Pull her by the nose.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pull it off: no matter for spoiling her face if she be dead.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Wring her by the little finger.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Her little finger is ringed; and I will wring it from her.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: No robbing the dead slip.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why should the dead partake of living ceremonies?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Cast water on her face.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Blow wind in her face. Can water make one alive that's dead? unless it be hot water.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Her spirits are returned; give her more air.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A woman's spirits? they are devilish sure: I had best conjure them back again.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Where am I! what a pleasant vision
Pleased my dead slumbers, and presented joys.
As I was passing through th'eternal shades
Towards Elysium, one of fates ministers
Told me I should return; and this same day
Enjoy my Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: What's he should own that name! wonder and doubt
Have raised a war within me, look up mistress:
You shall not want what comfort we can give you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Defend me gentle powers: yet ye shall never
O'ertake my heart: that's still with Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: For some blessed oracle to unfold the meaning
Of this so oft repeated name.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Ere you return me to my angry uncle.
My soul shall fly and meet with his embraces.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: What mean you gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You are murderers
Of that content in me goodness would cherish ▪
You serve the purposes of a passionate man
For base reward; and that shall render you
Base to opinion.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pray sir, let me conjure down this devil in her tongue; 'twill raise tempests else. Murderers, and base! Pray gentlewoman, to whom speak you all this?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: To you, the injurers of my true love
And Worthgood's.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Mistress, we know you not; and all your words
Appear distraction: nor can they satisfy
Our yet amazement.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: If you are not such
As my too fearful apprehension thought you,
pray, what are ye?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Such as do compassionate
Your feeling sorrows, and would comfort you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You'll then perform an act of piety
Worthy record. Since my distress hath made me
The object of your pity; pray conduct me
To some near house, for I am wondrous faint.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Go home with her daughter; use your best care in administering to her: we know not what fate depends upon it. When I have walked the round I'll return. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: But pray Cicely, withal, neglect not my breakfast. Rising early and walking gets us good stomachs: yet I could be content to fast with such laced mutton and a good cullis more than hal●e a morning.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: What passions fight within me, that beget
Several constructions of this accident?
But what my hope interprets cannot be.
How apt is misery to dream that blessings
Are all immediate, and no underworkings
Of means and counsel! I'll not flatter it;
('tis but th'effect of passion) but return
To my delight of labour. Saw you the herd
Last night sirrah?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: And how fed they?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: With their mouths.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: You'll not leave your saucy wit, until it be beaten out of you.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'T would be but saucily done of it to leave me so: but if it will not keep me from beating, I'll keep it no longer; but be mannerly. The dear fed well sir, only a mischance. Some cuckold's cur (For I saw him run towards London) had pulled down two or three young dear.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: And what did you with them?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
I sent a fawn to a wanting poet, a friend of mine; who I presume will make profitable use of it. Dress it in
some lamentable epitaph and dedicate to his ningle: whose compassion to ●ounty must redeem his lavendered plush, and commend him again to converse with sack and good company.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: You have surely gleaned from that poet.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Something to make people laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Venus did you with the rest?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A longing lady in the strand had a pricket. Then I sent a sore to barber-surgeons' hall. A little sore makes them a great feast.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Well sirrah, round you the South side oth' park; and meet me at the great oak. I'll this way.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pray stay sir, who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: He seems a discontented gentleman. Some dueller perhaps.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Some hot spurred gallant, that got a drunken fever last night, and must bleed this morning.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Perhaps to revenge an affront done his mistress.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: His common mistress you mean sir.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: It needs no adjective the sense is common enough.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: So is the creature; a cart take them. They have infected more honest alehouses with bad names, than cakes and cream will ever restore again. A wench is grown a necessary appendix to two pots at Tottenham court.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: To your walk sirrah. I'll observe him.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: And I'll home to observe how I can sleep after early rising. If my master should catch me napping, 'tis but dreaming a lie to excuse it. I'll persuade him 'tis as true prophecy as Booker's almanac. Exit.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: After so many longings to salute
The welcome light, it hath betrayed my sense
to worse affliction, then if sights privation
Had made it useless; since it wants the object
Can both delight and feed it, back blushing morn
To thy Mygdonian bed; there shake the dew
From thy wet locks; and teach thy guilty shame
To die that red in an eternal black,
Unless it bring more comfort.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Discontent
Rides on his forehead; and doth seem to trample
Upon his soul's dejection. Would I knew him.
Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis a fair salute.
I do return your wish.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Sir, you must pardon me
If I seem curious in some few demands.
My office and this place are privilege
For more than questions. Pray sir what are you?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: This sure is Marrowbone-park, and he the keeper.
A gentleman that comes not to offend you.
I spoil no game: you see I am unfurnished
Of instruments for such a wanton mischief.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: But sir, without a better satisfaction
I must suspect you still. Mere recreation
To walk for health seldom invites young gallants
To leave their beds so early. I must have more.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Must saucy groom! can any patience
Construe it manners? Your rude compulsion shall not
Enforce me to express so weak a spirit,
Whilst I have hands, and this.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: At that guard sir?
Then this must countercheck it. Either tell me
Your name, condition, and your business here;
By my just anger for this foul provoking
I shall not spare you else.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: How happy now
Might this occasion make me, were she lost
beyond that hope which whispers her yet safety!
I must preserve myself . Yet if thou triumph'st
In my submission, 'cause I had rather lose
A little outward credit to prevent
Worse mischief, know I can devise revenge,
Shall be a fair example for b●se difference
From the pretence of any borrowed power
To overdo it's duty. My name's Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Enough; that word hath power to check the force
Of any passion, though the hottest rage
Enslamed it to be active.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Here's a change.
Why sure my name's a spell. How it hath calmed
The tempest of his fury!

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: What black star
Was found th'ascendant in my crooked birth:
That all my life's sad accidents should be
Such pregnant ills begetting one another!
One sudden rashness in a moment might
Perhaps have mined him my duty honours:
Making this hand a mover to his death,
Whose life I ought to cherish.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: What wouldst else?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Nothing but pardon sir; or if you please
Th'occasion brought you hither. Lost you no company?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: It cannot sure be fear that makes me jealous.
I dare the worst of fate. Be he an actor
In my pursuit, I'll venture all at once.
I have lost a gentlewoman, and doubt her safety:
If any chance hath guided you to find her,
Do not delay my satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: I joy that chance made me the instrument
Of such a good. Please you to follow me.
I'll guide you to this pensive one, that grieves
More your feared loss then her own misery.
She named you oft; when (By her fit transported)
recovering from a swoon, she thought herself
Surprised by some that meant her injury.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Shall I give faith? my resolution's mad;
Yet it shall try th'event. Despair may bring
A good success to an indifferent thing. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Frank and George, as walking to Totenham-covet.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: Fie Frank; there's such a disproportion,
'Twill ne'er be brought to an equality.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why George, dost think th'exterior goods of fortune,
Or titular greatness that derives itself
From larger springs, and slows to swell the blood
With attributes of gentle, or of noble
Can make the difference such, that the free soul
Must have the limits of her large desires
Prescribed by them? Nature's impartial:
And in her work of man prefers not names
Of ancestors ▪ she sometimes forms a piece
For admiration from the basest earth
That holds a soul: and to a beggar's issue
Gives those perfections make a beauty up;
When purer moulds polished and glossed with titles,
Honours and wealth, bestow upon their bloods
Deformed impressions; objects only fit
For sport or pity.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yet never can the mixture
Of gold with clay make any transformation
Of that base matter into purer metal.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The chemistry of love can surely do it.
Wedlock confers all honour that's a husband's
Upon his wife.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: And therefore you will marry
A milk wench; one that's drudge unto necessity.
'Twould be a credit to that long continuance
Of noble matches which your ancestors
Have linked to the chain of their own bloods ▪
To make the series of their families
Spread in so many glorious divisions.
Come, let my counsel guide these passive fires
To flame aright, and send their pyramids
More upwards. Let the grosser stuff that feeds them,
By an inversion, choke them. From advice
Men must choose wives, not passion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is fair:
Upon her person all the graces wait,
And dance in rings about her. Her bright eye
Is loves chief mansion where he keeps his court.
Envy not fair ones, if my fancy doth
Give all your dues to her, save only those
Which your defects supply from wanton art.
Her white and red she borrows not from any
Cosmetic drugs; nor puzzles the invention
Of learned practitioners for oil of talxe
To blanch an Ethiops skin. Lilies and roses
Are figures fitting common beauties: hers
Wants a comparison but its proper self.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You swell her praise too high; so mean a subject fits not these raptures.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She's a subject, George,
For larger volumes than invention
Yet ever filled with flattering hyperboles.
The very thought of her hath strained my heartstrings
Up to a pitch of joy; whose music makes
My spleen dance lusty measures.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: If she be
So rare a piece, her low condition
Makes me suspicious she's some common wanton
Lurks in that mask for safety.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Did not friendship
Restrain't, I should be angry: nay more; punish
So great a sin against her innocence.
I have laid all the baits that might entice
Apt inclination to sweet wickedness;
But could not catch her that way. She hath shunned them
With witty scorn, and such imperious checks
Have made me blush at my intentions soulenesse:
Which now is cleared with noble resolution
To give my hot desires their satisfaction
In fair embraces, such as the reverence
Of lawful wedlock sweetens.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Virtuous policy.
Kill reputation, that you may preserve
A little better conscience. Any judgement
Would make a fair construction of my life,
That surfeits in delights, and plays the epicure
In all variety and choice of pleasures
Sooner then of thy act. Where ills do want
A fair excuse (As thine doth) they are doubled.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: When thou hast seen her, thou wilt soon acknowledge
In what a misty error thy invectives
Have lost themselves.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Nay rather hide her from me.
She may raise motions; and if I should rival thee,
I must be served: nothing was ere devised
To fright libidinous nature from it's proneness,
That can restrain me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Shalt not make me jealous ▪
Her soul is guarded with so many virtues
Temptations cannot better it: and i'th' way
of noble love (Though yet she never sung
The music of consent) I dare prefer
Myself the first accepted.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Still be confident.

div.head: The second scene.
To them Changlove, Stitchwell, and his wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Some city loving couple.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: What's that gallant?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Surely 'tis will Changelove;
The Proteus of affection: one that varies
As many shapes of love as there are objects.
But what that she-thing is I do not know.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She seems a handsome piece. That opportunity
Would play the bawd a little.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You'd be nibbling.
Changelove is my acquaintance. If they come this way (As 'tis most likely tottenham-court's the end of their early walking) I'll be thy introduction. Let's walk softly.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Whilst I do ruminate some policy.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Besides the recreation sir, 'tis healthful .

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: Indeed sloth dulls the spirit's activeness.
And too much sleeping blunts the senses quickness;
Though some be very needful; their affects
Are the preservers of their instruments.
I love early rising.

sp.speaker: Mris. St.
sp.p: But methinks a nap in a morning's good.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: True mrs. Stitchwell; when the brain hath purged
Itself of grosser fumes, the fancy yields
Such solace to the inward waking sense
In pleasant dreams, that I have often wished
Those shadows real which they have presented;
or their continuance to eternity.
Indeed I love to sleep in the morning.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: But stirring and exercise, I say.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you would use it in bed then.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: I tell you Mr. Changelove though I am a tailor I keep servants that are stout knaves. I love them well, and they look well to my business. On holidays I give them leave to use exercise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes husband, your finisher is a pretty a fellow as ever did tradesman or his wife service. He pitcheth the bar, and throws the stone; it doth me good to think of it.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: I have a cornish-lad that wrestles well, and hath brought home rabbits every Bartholmew-tide these five years. At stool ball I have a northwest stripling shall deal with ever a boy in the strand.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Now you speak of a ball, I would we had one here; 'tis a commendable exercise: the great physician Galen wrote a book, de exercitations parvae pilae.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What's that, pray sir?

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Concerning the exercise of the little ball.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It seems great physicians will busy themselves about small things: but they are not of my mind.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: How likest the project?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As the end proves it; howsoever, it promiseth fairly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: They are arrived: let us prepare ourselves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mr. Changelove; a happy day follow this pleasant morning.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Worthy friend, I return your salute with double wishes: pray know this gentleman and his bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The day must needs be fortunate, that begins with such fair omens.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pray sir, why doth that gentleman shun your company? I hope we fright him not. It had been manners to salute me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He always doth that by attorney mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Then I must pay the fees.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The truth is, he is a great woman-hater.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now out upon him. I thought he was gelt, he is so fat. Beast that I was to be so unmerciful to a dumb thing; I had a dog served so for the same purpose.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is a disposition in his will,
Not a defect of power.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: How said you sir? cannot that gentleman endure women?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Hardly their sight at distance. 'tis affliction
Unto his very soul to hear their virtues
Discoursed, unless in scorn.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: A strange unmanly humour: I love not that.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: May all the curses our injured sex can study, fall upon him for it: and I think we can curse.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I know, to him my company is dear;
And our intentions have the self same end
Of mutual enjoying: now, with what dejection
He doth expect I should divide myself
From you, may be conceived.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I beseech you kind sir leave us not.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: I should love some witty plot upon him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: He is my friend: yet I would gladly aid
In any easy mischief, that might aim
At his reclaiming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let's get him arraigned as one was in a play. Let me alone to aggravate his indictment to the jury; which shall be twelve midwives of my acquaintance: yet I'll be sworn I never used any of them.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: I have it.

sp.speaker: Stich.
sp.p: Pray first hear mine: let's run to Totenham-court for a wager.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent; so his gross body's toil
To follow us, shall be our laughter.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Right: or if he stay behind, let my wife alone to vex him.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: Let's run then: 'tis a brave Olympic exercise;
I love it well; but how shall we dispose
Of all these cumbers?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let us not be footmen.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.l: Indeed a seeming careless stayed formality
In such like wantonnesses best becomes
A gentleman. I love it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Forwards then.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: The wager?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Every man his dozen. Exeunt running.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why sweetheart; why husband; why John; do you leave your wife behind, to be taken up by everybody ? Now the love of man's society defend me from this abuser of creation. Come not near me thou man of clouts; thou malkin of virility; thou half woman, and all beast: or with these nails I will tear out thine eyes, and all the double things are left about thee.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Be milder gentle mistress. There's nothing in me
Appears unto myself so full of guilt
It should deserve reproach from you a stranger.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: There's nothing in you indeed sir; your friend hath given me your character. You pretend to hate women, because women have reason to hate you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I hate women!
Now by my love of pleasure, no delight
Hath any relish on the wanton palate
Of my desires; unless some mixture season it
That is derived from them.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes sir; you may take delight in them, but they little in you. Come not too near, there's infection in it: my blood desires no freezing. The summer of my youth is not yet half spent; or if it were autumn with me, high feeding and ease requires something.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She takes me for an eunuch. Sure my friend
Hath overdone his part; and drawn the counterfeit
Too near the life of truth. Sweet mistress hear
the language of my heart that cannot gloss
My plainer thoughts with superficial words.
I love you; my desires are thoroughly fired,
And burn my blood: which but your free enjoying
Nothing can quench.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, I am a woman sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I think you are; and one made up for pleasure,
More than the dull converse of what's defective.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You say true sir: I hear it with a heavy heart.
But I hope sir, you would not have me make my husband a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Fie, that's a gross construction; only shame
And common knowledge doth it, not the act
Of a wife's wantonness.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I need no instructions for secrecy. Trust me a handsome gentleman. The wickedness of his friend to believe him so. Dare you kiss me sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A pledge for what should follow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You shall do what you will with me, but making my husband cuckold.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No more of that. Nay, this way.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What, back again! No by my strand-honesty. I'll to Tottenham-court after my husband. If there be that necessity at any time that I must make my husband a cuckold, I'll do it before his face: any citizens wife can do it behind her husband's back.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Your will disposeth mine: we there may find
Handsome conveniences; and I'll renew
My counterfeit of woman-hater: it
May cast a mist before his jealous eyes
Would watch us else. Exeunt.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: Enter Ciceley and Bellamy in one another's clothes.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: I hope you're satisfied: but to what end this change should serve, I would fain be instructed.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I'll tell you. When we feared pursuit, we left our horses, and the high way. The horses are surely found; and by them my being hereabouts may be conjectured. Now this disguise shall help me to scape their search.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Now out upon't. Had I no better an opinion of your honesty, then of your wit (Both which smell all together of the country) I would again leave you to seek out your own danger. You have gentle-fied me with your clothes; and you are handsome enough in mine: for though I am but a milk-wench, I ever loved neatness. Now you shall personate my maid, and wait upon me to London; I'll personate you, and if any thing rise from the mistake, we'll turn it to the best use. If I find not out your sweetheart, let me never be counted a prophetess: and I am sure I have foretold weather from the turning up of my cow's tail.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Dispose me as you please, I dare the worst
Of my malicious. Now love hath armed me
With better resolution.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: In this disguise I'll meet the gallant courts me every morning at Tottenham-court, and sound the depth of his pretended honest meaning. My condition is too low to win upon his desires to marry me: and the other thing without it, he shall never have.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Why Ciceley, Cicely, I say my breakfast a quick supply of meat, drink and sleep, or I rage presently.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Bless me, who's that?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: My father's man.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: He'll spoil all. To them Slipp hastily.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Be you confident.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Where's this maggoty-pie of marrowbone? Come you clean washed chitterling, and give me my breakfast. How now Cicely, where hath your face been? at the painters? Hay-day; Ciceley's own face, and this mistress die for love Ciceley-side. Now I swear by hunger (And that's a strong oath) I think women have more fegaries than the devil would have clients, if he were a lawyer and pleaded without fees.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Keep counsel sirrah you had best; and if my father ask for me, tell him I will not be lost long. So fare you well. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: You will not be lost long: he is likely to have a sweet match of it that finds you. Yet I could be content my seven years' service might be so rewarded. But the baggage is as coy as an alderman's eldest daughter: she hath beaten me a hundred times (Coward as I was for suffering it) for attempting to kiss her. But now I will revenge it upon her cream-bowls; over whose sweets I will triumph.

div.head: The fourth scene.
To him keeper, Worthgood.
div.p: New mischief; I am again delayed. If I forbear my breakfast but two minutes longer, my guts will shrink into minikins: which I bequeath the poor fiddlers at Tottenham-court, for a May-day's legacy.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: You're welcome to this roof; too mean a covering
For such a guest.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Your first sir hath enriched it.
And hallowed it into a temple. Pray sir.
Conduct me to the altar, where I may
Pay the due sacrifice of my desires
To her; and thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Slip, call my daughter.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Which daughter sir? your daughter gentlewoman, or your gentlewoman daughter?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Your trifling's unseasonable sirrah.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why sir, ciceley's no more plain Cicely, but Cicely in laced satin. The gentlewoman and she are run out of themselves one into another.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: But where are they?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: For ought I know, run away one with another.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Run you after, and call them back.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible: who knows which way they are gone. Besides, 'tis a mist would choke a brewer's horse; I cannot see one hand for the other.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Sir, my suspicion prompts me you are treacherous:
And these fair seeming undertakings traps
To catch me.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Sir, you make a worse construction
Of my good meaning, then so fair expressions
Can any way deserve. Pray sir go with me,
We'll overtake them.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: I will share the pains;
And venture once again to try you thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Follow you sirrah. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A killing command. The best is, it will break my heart, no matter then for my belly. Hunger, I defy thee; revenge I hug thee. I will lead you a wild-goose chase, till we come to Tottenham court: where I will score two dozen, and reckon with mine hostess maid, whose belly I have raised with umbles. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are the Olympian, sir.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Do you think gentlemen I'd let you outstrip me at exercise? I'll jump with ye for a dozen more.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Pray sir let's jump: I love it mightily.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My breathes not yet recovered. By this time sir. your wife hath converted my friend to a civiller disposition.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Let her alone. If she do it not, I durst forswear exercise; and that would be the greatest vexation.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Greater then if your maid should drop the candle on your festival satin doublet?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Or the cats piss upon your military feather?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Or an inferior neighbour be preferred for a common counsel man?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Mere trials to the forbearing of exercise.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Or if a gallant should deal with your wife in your absence for body covering, and give her court payment.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: A very likely matter. She that goes thrice a week to morning exercise, and will make repetition over sweet meats at a gossipping. I tell ye gentlemen, I have trusted her to a mask, and the inns a court revelling: she knew the way home again without a crier. She hath converted a hundred of her purer neighbours, by her example.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Here's more than city confidence. But shall we enter?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: You're welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Chang ▪
sp.p: A handsome room sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: The best in the house sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your wife's come, sir.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Welcome sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Kind gentlemen, hold my heart, o. Nay one at once: pray hold it hard, o ▪

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: What's the matter chuck?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
O my breath: there's not so much wind left in me, as would make a noise to be excused with the creaking of ones shoe: o ▪ you are a kind husband to leave me
behind. Had it been with one that had loved a woman, showed her the nearest way, or laid her down upon his cloak when she had been weary. But I think I fitted him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And beshrew him if he fitted not you.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Here he is likewise.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You blow hard George.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, shall we walk in.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I would enjoy my friend a little here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You shall enjoy your friend sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And what success?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Why dost not hear her promise?
You shall enjoy your friend. She's pliant Frank
Unto my wishes: nothing no remains
But to deceive her husband; thou must aid me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Wouldst have me pandarize?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: I'll do't for thee.
These are sweet sins, and only do intend
The pleasure of desire, which would be killed
With two much scruple.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What place is this? A common alehouse?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Fear you nothing, but put on confidence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have seen that face, the figure's in my heart.
'Tis surely she: her habit cannot mock
My knowing sense. I'll venture on the trial.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: This is his milkmaid sure. I still suspected
'Twas some disguised name to conceal a mistress.
Now by my life she's fair; I envy him;
And my desires have almost tempted me
To put in for a share: but friendship cheques it.
She may perhaps be virtuous, and well born.
And worthy his resolves: my city beauty
Shall serve at this time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Didst thou think that mask
Could veil thee from my souls distinguishing?
Wherein thy form's impressed, which fancy shows me
At every change of thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Clothes have not altered
My person nor condition. I am still
Plain Cicely and your handmaid. This exchange
Proceeds but from an honest merriment:
And when you understand the story right,
You'll make a fair construction.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Twere a sin
To think amiss of thee; tears cannot expiate ▪
When thou art mine, I'll feed thy appetite
With pleasures best variety. Tailor's daily
Shall shape proportions for thy dainty body,
To make invention pregnant of new fashions.
Th'exchange shall be thy wardrobe to supply
Thy will with choice of dressings t'hearken out ▪
A jewel to adorn thee, if the value
Exceed not my estate; I'll sell it all
To purchase thy content.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Your promises
Are much too large. My too unworthy service
Cannot deserve to be commanded by you.
Gallant I'll try you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Th'ecstasy hath made me
Forget my friend: 'tis she George changed in habit

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I am your servant fair one, and my heart
Vow's an obedience when your commands
Assign me any task.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I do not like
The courtship of these gallants: 'tis gross flattery,
And tends I fear to ill.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come dearest will you
accept the entertainment of this place?
Some worthy company within expects me.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: I shall strain modesty, you excusing it.
Come maid.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Why should I fear; that have defence
From Worthgood's love, and mine own innocence? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.p: You're welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Now my parrot of froth, whose mouth is lined with tapestry; what company is in the house?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: None of your acquaintance but Mr. Changelove.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Will Changelove? prithee call him hither.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: I shall sir; by and by. Some stewed prunes for the two costive citizens in the bull's head; and more rolls for the three tailors in the Smithfield-lyon.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: How shall we spend the day Sam? Exit.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Let's home to our studies and put cases.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Hang cases and books that are spoiled with them. Give me Johnson and Shakespeare; there's learning for a gentleman. I tell thee Sam, were it not for the dancing-school and playhouses, I would not stay at the inns of court for the hopes of a chief justiceship.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Time would be better spent in reading laws,
Teaching our knowledge how to argue doubts:
For in our after-states such may arise
That without policy's help may ruin it.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p:
Formality; a grave youth in a gown. Thou think'st 'tis becoming to walk thus to Tottenham-court, and at
home so punctual in conformity. I had rather a French consumption should wear my hair off then a round cap.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis not to make it my profession,
(Although in some it be most necessary)
(For how can government and laws subsist
Without their ministers, whose skill and judgement
Distinguish right from wrong) but to be able
To manage what's mine own, as time shall send it,
You are likely to inherit fair possessions,
Gained by a father's industry; perhaps
With some contention, and conveyances
May be defective: were't not better far
Yourself could understand it, than to trust
The honesty or skill of a bought counsel?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Hang state: I took no pains to get, why then should I take any to keep it? if it will stay, so 'tis: if not, shopkeepers that will trust, shall be paid when they can get it. A law of necessity Sam, and always in force with gallants.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I had rather hear another resolution.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Will Changelove, well met at Tottenham-court.
What made thee rise so early?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: The company of half a man: expound my riddle, and be a whole Oedipus.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: It must be more than thy tailor.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Right, his wife; who being half of himself, makes up the third part a half man. I love his company man, and pay him with nothing but courtesies: a Tottenham-court's kindness is principal, interest and security.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: What shall we drink? Ale?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I love it best; the old English natural drink. But can this gentleman study a●ter ale?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: If I avoid the excess.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Ale's muddy: what think you of beer?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: I love beer best. The planting of hops was a rare projection in the Dutch; it hath taught some of them English naturally.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Shall we hunt today will? I heard the common cry abroad.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Hunting! 'tis sport to make immortal activeness
Even in the dullest earth. A well-mouthed cry
Outdoes the spheres in music. Gods themselves
Have left their fabulous heaven, to put on
The shapes of hunters: courting such delights
In these disguises, that hath made them wish
Th'exchange of their ethereal government
To live with mortals. I love hunting dear.
What saith your friend?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Indeed sir, my affection
Is better pleased with solitary study:
A sober morning's walk, is exercise
Enough for me.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: You are to be commended.
Why, contemplation is the very being
Of man's delight: it shows his nobler part
Converse with things divine; the nimble soul
Climbs by it to a height of happiness.
I must confess I love it.Music

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Is there music with the company you left?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: And good too: 'tis company of that curiosity, ordinary stuff will not please them.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Would thou wouldst enter me into their acquaintance; we might have a dance.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Why, I love dancing too. Agility
Commends the good composure of one's body;
and graceful garbs are taking. No perfection
Doth make the object of a handsome man
So pleasing in a lady's eye, as dancing.
This room's more spacious: I'll invite them hither.

div.head: The third scene.
To them Frank, Ciceley, Stitchwell, wife, Bellamy, and George behind the women.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The room's possest.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You may command a resignation.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Please you t'admit us; we would fain partake
Your worth and company.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your friends will Changelove?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Yes, noble sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: They're welcome to my knowledge.
Numbers addition will increase our mirth,
And swell it to more height.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Arm me now confidence,
And teach my tongue, that never spoke untruth
From a consideration, practice lying,
And the denial of my proper self.
It is my brother, he'll discover me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis surely she: they're all her lineaments.
Had I never seen her; had not knowing sense
Power to distinguish, natural instinct
Would tell me 'tis my sister. Why disguised?
And why come hither? it hath wrapped my reason
In mists of wonder. Yet I cannot fear
She hath betrayed her honour to base wantonness.
She had a guard of virtues; else hypocrisy
Taught her to seem a saint, and paint that goodness
With a false colour. Know you not my sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is not your name Bellamuel?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Neither sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Denies herself.
There's something in't above my reach of fear.
Passion forbear me, and I'll work with policy,
To find the scope of all.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: A sweet young gentleman.
Is this your sweetheart maid?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Is she your servant?
I would have called her kinswoman for resemblance
She hath with one of mine.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Your aunt or cousin?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Means she in the mystical sense of ill?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Shall we dance gentlemen? Musicness, and let activeness freeze! Shall I use you sweet mistress?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Kindly sir, or I am waspish. A wasp you know hath a sting.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Please that gross gentleman?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By no means sir: dancing will hurt his sciatica.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Do you know him then?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yes, and will know him better if he come near me.
He is one into whom the spirit of Swetnam's crept.
I hope sir you are of a kinder disposition to our sex.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: You see mistress I am for their company any way.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Pray sir let's go nearer the women.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Pray sir forbear: you'll not compel me rudely.
Perhaps there's an aversion in my nature.
The company of women's mine affliction.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: My wife shall vex you then.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: And I love man's society: solid souls,
Void of all light impressions; whose discourse
Tends not to superficial compliment,
But hath more sense than sound.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are for dancing;
Possess my room,

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: The women's creature sir.
There's magic in their company that charms
All masculine affections, but of pleasure
In their enjoying. I'll spin or thread their needles,
Read Spenser and th' Arcadia for their company.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll dance with you Mr. Changelove.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: One cup more, I'll be for the exercise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You'll have more anon husband, than your head will well carry.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She means horns.
Which if I fail to give her, may I turn
Chastities convert, and be mortified
From my concupiscence with hourly discipline.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why how now husband? you'll be tippled presently.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Hold good wife, before strangers? Tother dozen, and then I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you were gone once for me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: So would I.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Gentlemen, a health to —

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whom sir?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: All the cuckolds in the strand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fie husband, you forget yourself. Nay, gentlemen he is such another man; when he hath got a cup or two he'll not stick to abuse his betters. I beseech you bear with him, I shall be ready to bear with any of you.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Wife, you shall drink a health to all the cuckold-maker in Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You mean wrestler's sweetheart; you are so taken with your Cornish prentice. I tell ye gentlemen, hearing him talk the other day of the hug, I wished him to show me what 'twas: the stiff knave presently gives me a fall: but it was upon a soft bed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Otherwise there had been danger.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Come sweet mistress, the other dance.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Will you make one sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Alas fair mistress, my gross body wants
A mimic activeness.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: But you can move sir?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Bestir your stumps a little sir. Are women such bugbears, especially handsome ones? for I have been flattered.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Well said wife; to him wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I durst undertake yet, had you one of us in a corner.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How she instructs me! nay then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you be gone George?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: After him wife, put him to't, and tickle him home.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I'll warrant husband I'll bring him into play. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: It seems this gentleman loves not the company of women.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: At least wise 'tis pretended. Were't a plot
To gull her husband, I should love it dear.
Why did not I attempt it, that have had
More opportunities than ever made
Sin fruitful in the pleasure? If't be so,
The next share shall be mine. I love a wench
As well as he or any.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Tother health, and then farewell,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mr. Stitchwell is your name?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: A tailor in the strand; and I am as good a man there as deputy tagg in the city, though he think himself an alderman's fellow, and no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You mind cuckolds much: good sir remember yourself.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: By your leave then; I must, and I will, I will and I must.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What must you sir?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Why, you may do what you will; and I will do what I list. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: The tailor's paid.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: By your favour, 'tis a lie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
And his wife too by this. Follow me gentlemen,
and if he prevent it not, we'll share some pastime. Sweet, I'll return presently. Exeunt men.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Can my chaste thoughts within their spotless circuit
Retain a good opinion of this gentleman,
Who gives free scope to his libidinous will
In actions that stain conscience?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Can my ills
Grow to a greater height? my honour's danger
Runs equal with my persons.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: He hath courted
Almost beyond resistance, (Had not goodness
Preserved me white) to sully me with lust;
And failing offered marriage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Can a brother
Construe this place, disguise, and company
Less than a lapse from virtue in a sister,
Who laboured more to be good really,
Then ever hypocrite did to appear so.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: I must not trust. Besides, mine eye hath seen
An object that delights it; and desire
Begins to burn my bosom with new flames
I yet never felt. 'tis an ambitious love,
And must be checked. Why? sure my birth's more noble:
My spirit argues it, which never yet
Harboured a common thought; but all above
The lowness of my fortune. How now mistress?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Distressed beyond recovery. 'twas my brother;
Whose eye no sooner found me, but his looks
Expressed a troubled soul: but when he heard
My tongue deny myself; what passions then
Possessed him, may be thought.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Is he your brother?
Fear not to be discovered: I have plots
To circumvent him, and prepare his temper
For mild impressions. Enter tapster.
Prithee friend show us a private room.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: With convenience mistress.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: For a retirement.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: This way mistress. I smell the reward of a knave's office: howsoever sin thrives by wickedness. Frothfilled cans and over-reckonings will hardly raise a stock to set up with. Now will I inform the gallants. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, forbear. Is this a place to make ones husband a cuckold in?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Let not such weak excuses rob my hopes
Of that delight, for whose enjoying
Danger and all that weakness can be frighted with —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, talk not to me of weakness. The servants of the house will suspect us presently.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Be expeditious then, we lose that time
Might make the pleasure fruitful.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Indeed sir I durst e'en venture to make him cuckold, might I be sure you would get a boy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That's doubtless, sweet.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And shall he be like the father?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: As ever citizens son was.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I mean my husband.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I am a courtier.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Kind sir, you even deserve it for your policy. But I am so afraid.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Mischief on these delays.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Sweetheart, wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Vexation racks me.
Prevented at the point of such a happiness!

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Come chuck and hold my head.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, hide yourself:

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Happily, here's an empty tub. To them stitch.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: My head aches wife; where art chicken?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Here husband. You must press upon women's retirement.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: O my stomach; 'tis very sick.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Empty it in the fields then; let not the servants take notice you are such a sloven.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Why not in that rub?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fie beast: defile a necessary implement of housewifry? This 'tis to drink healths to cuckolds. You might have been one yourself, were not I the honester woman; which is more than many of your neighbours can say for themselves.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: To them Frank, Changelove, James, Sam, and a little after them a wench with a pail of water.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Stitchwell? Fie, give out man, and steal away.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: O gentlemen my head, my head; o gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: methinks your forehead's swollen sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Truly no sir. There's no more than what hath been ever since I was his wife; fifteen years and upwards, a long time of barrenness.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What the devil make all these gentlemen in my dame's washhouse? Get ye up to your chambers with a vengeance.

div.stage: Powres the water into the tub.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I wonder where my friend is.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hold, hold; I am drowned.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: George, what made you there?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Mischief on you sir: you have spoilt me a pail of conduit water cost me many a weary step the
fetching; beside the falls my sweetheart slip gave me.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Alas good gentleman; he hid himself from my wife, and see what's happened.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Hell take your wife and you. Accursed women,
That in your curse made man so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fie George, scold presently after your cucking.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Diogenes in dolio.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: And lamentation.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Come forth George: now the comedy is ended, away with the disguise.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Women or devils,
Made fair to be destruction's instrument.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You seem to compassionate the mischance:

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.l: Good heart ▪ but that he cannot endure a woman,
She should kiss him for amends.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I think it would grieve any woman. I came hither for something else then to be railed at.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.l: Let's vex him no more gentlemen. Come wife,
He go sleep a little. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: There will be a safe opportunity for me. I love this cuckold-making.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Frank, though yourself intend a reformation,
You might forbear me: this was your own plot.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why mine? I never had resolution yet
So stayed, but I could alter it for pleasure:
Nor can I hate or envy it in others.
I am sorry George you should drink water after your sweetmeats. To them tapster.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Do not abuse me lest I think revenge:
I am almost tempted to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: The gentlewoman hath withdrawn herself.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: She in the satin gown. You know my meaning sir, she's as right —

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Thanks honest robin. Here's for thee.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: I must thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I'll take the first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: The gentlewoman is retired sir.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: You know my meaning. She's as right —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pox on your pandarising.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: How now sir? I wonder what quantity of maiden modesty went to your making up. Few gentlemen of your complexion would have been angry with an honest tapster for such intelligence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My sister turned a common prostitute?
I must discover it.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: The gentlewoman's gone into another chamber sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: She in the satin gown. There's a bed: you know my meaning. She's as right —

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are a rogue sirrah.Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Good sir, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mutter that thought again: I'll cut thy tongue out ▪

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: And kill anon, anon sir. But cold rewards. Had none any better; panders would never purchase. Exit.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'll take the tapster's word, and try.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, let's up again. By this time George your sorrow's dry. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: And why should you think so slip?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: If I find them not, count me no wiser than an apothecary, that looked for Jews ears on an old pillory; when the dead wood bore none but scriveners.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Inquire diligently, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I will sir, and arm myself like a country juror: I cannot hold out too fast till I have given up my verdict. Exit.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: My patience sir hath hitherto made fair
The outside and appearance of that good
Your promise seemed to mean me. Circumstance
Doth now instruct my fear, that this credulity
May be my danger. Treachery oft lurks
In compliments. You've sent so many posts
Of undertakings, they outride performance.
And make me think your fair pretences aim
At some intended ill; which my prevention
Must strive t'avert. Then good sir, leave me.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Sir, though my outside's mean; I have a soul
Instructed in all dues belong to man.
I never yet misused a common action
With a prepared dissembling. My intents
Are fairer than your jealousy, which lives
But in the darkness of your ignorance.
'Tis a blind humour, let discretion guide it:
That th'end of your own good be not perverted
By ill receiving of the hopeful means
My freeness offers.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: You have heard my story;
But why it should so stir compassion
In any stranger, counsel cannot well
Remove the doubt.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Why sir, I know a gentleman
Worthy in all things; but his crosser fortune
(On which mine had dependence as a servant)
Robbed him at once of all those gifts she lent him;
Estate, life, wife; his infant-issue left
To her blind pity. Can I think you then,
Without some feeling, hear the sad relation
Of a misfortune, is so like to that,
As if the self same inauspicious starsTo them slip.
Were both their means. The news sirrah.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Very bad sir. My incredulous hostess will not trust: therefore pray sir make haste; for without some supply
of drink I faint in the half way of my message.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Hast found them?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: There's hopes or so: I heard an inkling. The house swarms with gallants; some of which have surely taken up Cicely, paltry baggage, she plays the lady at least, and makes mincing faces like a country bride at the upper end of the table.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Pray sir let's in: we may perhaps find them here.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: O fate, unless thy guiding kinder prove,
Despair kills all my hope, and ends my love. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: O cakes and ale, if you your sweets deny,
Let slip despairing in a halter die.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Fear not mistress any of their attempts in my house: you have your instructions and my aid. Make use of any thing I own for your honest ends, and if you need my person, I am ready in my bar at your call. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: We thank you mistress.
Why should you fear the execution
Of my desires? why are women subject
To that disease? or else hath nature chose it
To show the difference? I was meant a man sure;
For I have masculine resolutions,
Which no deluding spirits can abuse
With their misguiding; nor imperfect moonlight
Mock with false shadows. Danger frights not me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Doubt of my loved friends safety (Without whom
My soul's abilities are dead to use)
Hath numbed the sense of action: I'm all passive.
Yet I have heard from him relations
Of horrid battles, and his person's danger;
Whenas the murdering canons choked the air
With their curled mists, their loud noise ushering death
To his black triumph. A little custom made it
To be my pastime. Those were dangers passed;
But these to come.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: You have a soldier sweetheart,
And no more courage! what a race of cowards
Would spring from that love's joining? for physicians
Say women have most right in the conception.
Were but our causes changed (Our cases are)
I'd tell this brother all; and if his love
From a pretence of care denied me aid,
I'd school him soundly. Come, come, you shall, tell
Your brother that I love him.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Love my brother?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Your brother mistress. If my beauty can
(Which has been flattered for a taking one)
Win upon his desires, I'll soon work him
To what you please. Nay, rather than the project
Should fail of a success, he shall enjoy me;
But fairly.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Aid me now discretion. Would you
Make mean agent to undo my brother;
And but for such mean ends?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Why gentlewoman,
Disparage not my low condition.
Perhaps misfortune meant it not my birth;
That might be noble as your own, though boasted
From th'herald's catalogue of dead ancestors.
My father oft hath told me when my fingers
Pressed the cow's dugs, and from their fullness drew
Abundance of white streams, that nature meant not
These limbs for labour. But this may appear
The flattery of myself.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Into what maze
My dangers lead me! I'th middle there's a monster,
If I go on, will ruin me: if back;
I want an Ariadnean clue of policy
To be my guide.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: If you'll preserve yourself
From a discovery, you must counterfeit
Some other passions; or clothe these in mirth.

div.head: The second scene.
To them James, presently after George.
div.p: How now maid? why left you the door open?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: 'Tis shut again sweet mistress. If it offend you, I will buy my pardon at your own rate.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: What would you have sir?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: A little pleasure sweet. Come, come, what's your price?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: You sure mistake me sir.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: As if I had not practised wenching sufficiently to understand a dissembled modesty: because I am a stranger, I'll come to your lodging when I know where 'tis. But say your price? half a crown?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Have I found you gallant? I am dearer sir; that's my maid's rate. The truth is I have my maidenhead yet, and have bargained with a gentleman below for it.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Let me have it; I'll double his reward.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: I love to be as good as my word. Sure sir he'd kill you if he knew of your attempt. That's he sir. Knock.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: And my young valour dare not encounter him.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Your city-born coward never make's fortunate whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Would I were safe.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Best hide yourself in this sir.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: A handsome convenience. When he's gone, release me.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Fear it not sir, but be sure you lie still. Open the door maid; and do you hear? get the key of the trunk.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What may this come to?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Pardon me fair one. My intrusion tends
To beg a happiness; please you to crown it
With your consent and welcome?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: What's in me
To grant, you shall command.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I take your word.
The pleasure of your bed. I will reward it
With a new gown and angels; dally not
In any coy denial.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Not in this place.
But if you please —Whisper.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: New jealousy instructs.
My fear this woman's naught, and such a one
As sells herself to sin. What fates conspire
To make me miserable?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: 'Tis a motion
Suits with my liking. The pains will make the pleasure
More sweet in the enjoying.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Courting her!
George, 'tis not friendly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Mischief on suspicion.
I've given you all the flattering commendations
That might confirm her love.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No more; I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I leave ye. Now to my practice of revenge,
and the delight it comprehends within it
Above Elysium. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dear, when shall my love
Be happy in enjoying what it makes
The object of desire? Shall this fair morning
Be consecrate to Hymen?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Worthy sir,
Such is the difference 'twixt your birth and fortune,
And my condition (Whose inferior aim
Dare not be levelled higher than it's equality)
Makes (Coward's policy,) fear, to be th'excuse
Of my delay. For were you satisfied
With that which you call pleasure; and satiety
Had taken the edge off, what's in me can whet
New appetite, and revive a dying love?
Your estimation branded with the infamy
Of a base choice: taunts from the mouth of envy:
Aspersions to beget a killing jealousy.
And when you shall reflect —

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Prithee no more
These needless doubts. I'm armed with preparations
For my resolves, that no assault can bitter.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Pardon me sir; there's ground of circumstance
To build a faith on, that your desires end
Is my enjoying for your senses pleasure.
Not the converse which love instructs the soul in.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why should false fears make such a bad construction?
Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: But I must search you thoroughly.
You're noble sir; and now I will unmask
This false complexion of an hypocrite,
Which hitherto deluded your opinion
But with a show of virtue. The truth is
My inclination's wanton; and this day
I meant to make a sale of that, for which
You have so fairly bid: my maidenhead.
You see I'm fitted for it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: The gentleman that left me, is the merchant.
A price is likewise set upon the ware.
The time and place of interchange appointed.
The means: a porter in that trunk must carry me
Unto his chamber: you seem troubled sir
At the relation.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis to try me sure:
She cannot mean it. How my thoughts rebel
Against their guide?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Troth sir, I must confess
Your person likes me better, and the love
You have professed deserves my gratitude.
Meet you this porter, and compel him with you;
You shall enjoy me first, and afterwards
When I set up the trade be still more welcome.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Should this be earnest. it would make me happy
Above mine own desire; and should she mock me,
'Twere but returning to my first intents.
Some way I must enjoy her. Shall this practice
Give me those sweets have been so long denied
With counterfeited modesty?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Be sure sir;
My tutor in the art left me instructions
To take the fairest offer.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: My reward
Shall treble his. Be constant to my pleasure,
I'll keep thee like a wife; and serve thy will
With full content.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: That as your liking pleaseth.
When you are weary, I'll but beg your bounty
For a new wardrobe to set up with.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How man's desire
Pursues contentment! 'tis the soul of action,
And the propounded reason of our life.
Yet as the choice appears, or gross or excellent,
we fly not from th'enjoying; but are changed
In our opinion either of the object,
Or of the means that works it. Why should I
Alter a resolution? The contentment
Is still the same: and a far easier means
Without that tie necessitates the will
To a sixth bounds. Besides, my credit's safe.
To keep a mistress youth's excuse may serve;
But an inferior match brands my posterity,
If equal blood commix not. Hence then scruple,
And all that frights saint conscience. Sweet I welcome
The freeness of your kind and loving promise
With as much joy, as can possess a heart
Made jovial by th'effect of all it's wishes:
Be constant to it.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Be you confident;
I cannot be diverted from my purpose:
The end's too pleasant, pray prepare yourself;
The time draws on.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And till my expectation
Ends in that full possession of delight,
Times wings are clipped. So farewell sweet till then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: And farewell base desires. May thy soul lust
Make thee still credulous, till abuse and shame
Teach thee amendment. What an orator
Is sin? that paints itself with golden words
Of pleasure and delight; as if the soul
Had it's eternal being and full powers
But for the senses satisfaction:
And their enjoying it creation's end.
Now to our comedy. Ha● fast asleep!
This fits our purpose. Lock it fast.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Will not the feathers choke him?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: He's armed against mischances. Give it the porter,
I must withdraw. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Now I perceive
goodness guides all her actions: her mind's brightness
Outshines her outward beauty. But what use
Can my misfortune make of't? yes; th'example
Shall teach me how to counterfeit, if I
Can force my passion to it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now wench, is all ready?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I have packed her up in't, like a bartholomew-baby in a box. I warrant you for hurting her.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis a good wench. I'll give thee a new gown for it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I thank you sir. When you are weary of my mistress, and cast her off (As I know you must have change) you shall have my maidenhead at the same rate if you please: I'll keep it for you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis a bargain.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: But two words to it. Pray sir use her never the worse for my promise.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: The better. I'll turn her off within this fortnight, and send for thee.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: O sir, 'tis not fit a servant should shift her mistress trencher before the bones are clean picked. You have flesh enough to hold out a month.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: It shall be a month then?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Be careful porter of your carriage.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Married? that I am to a freeman's widow, and I wear the citie-armes by her first husband's copy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: The porter is deaf sure.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Pray sir let me ask you one question.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Quickly then.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: How many maidenheads have you bought thus?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Some nineteen with thy mistresses.

sp.speaker: Bella ▪
sp.p: Pray sir, let mine make up the score: an even reckoning.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: It shall, it shall: here's for thee Robin.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: The trunk is worth more sir, besides the feathers that are in it. But to do you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Help him down stairs with it.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Here's a Tottenham-court project translated over the water from holland.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Farewell wench. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Adieu good sir, with your fair bedfellow that must be.
Had I my Worthgood here, this accident
Would strain my heart strings to a pitch of laughter,
And make my spleen dance. But his loss hath killed
All sense of joy. Ciceley returns.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Now mistress, what think you of it?
Have I not ta'en a course to punish lust?
At least wise with disgrace. Though custom calls
Those actions only honest, that are glorious
In public same; yet sometimes to dissemble
An ill that's not intended, when the end
Hath cleared it to opinion, it attains
The greater praise.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Indeed, I must confess
My fears possessed me strongly you were 'nough:
Nor is suspicion grounded on due circumstance
To be accounted ill. But now my knowledge
Instructs me better to commend your virtue;
And steer mine own course by the fair example
Of your discretion, were the like attempted
Upon my chastity.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Now must I practise unaccustomed impudence. By your leave gentle creatures: may I have my turn now for a little sport! Nay, nay, sweetheart, thou shalt serve: thy mistress is too dear; and I am loath to pay overmuch for repentance. 'tis but changing offices: let her hold the door for thee.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Pray sir, speak and mean civilly; you'll not be welcome else.

sp.speaker: Sam.
