sp.p: Good lady Light-heel; give your servant leave to practise the trade you have taught her. That such perfections as appear in this woman should be sold to every base desire. Come wench, thy brown complexion pleaseth me better than thy mistresses: thou dost not paint, and art the likelier to be wholesome.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Good gentleman, he is jealous, and would circumvent her.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Here's half a crown wench; methinks 'tis a fair rate. Ha! singer in the eye? Keep thy tears for penance in bride well. Cry when money's offered thee?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: O brother.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha! are you my sister?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Your sister Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why she's in the country at mine uncles,
Teaching her hand some neat industrious practice;
Or painting with her needle the rare form
Of some choice flower; to her busy servant
Discoursing morals; or perhaps at prayers,
Or meditation: these were her exercises;
Not prostitution. What an impudence
Is this imposture?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Temper your anger brother,
For it appears i'th wrinkles of your brow.
And let not passion burn your jealous fears
With an intemperate heat. I have a story
You'll pity, though all natural affection
Were quite extinguished.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then you are my sister?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Dissemble not those doubts; but hear me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No.
I'm deaf to all excuse. 'tis too apparent.
Possess me virtuous rage; make me the instrument
Of a religious justice.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Guard me innocence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O that the knowing soul, which can distinguish
Itself and powers; should yield her government
To the lascivious appetite of sense:
And under such a base subjection
Ruin her noble parts. True estimation
Is grounded on the actions of the mind:
And to determine bravely, well as honestly,
Must be the last, and most refined digestion
Of a high flying nature. Such should hers be.
She wanted not th'instruction, nor example
Of worthy parents, that honour is the most
Essential part of life, and valued above it.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Good gentleman, he's troubled.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O hypocrisy,
Thy painted shows must likewise mock our judgements
Into an apt credulity, that makes
Bad worse by the dissembling. Had she wanted
Or means of power or fortune to discover
This inclination; like the serpent numbed
With a long rigidness, forbears to sting
His warmers bosom, not because he hath not
A poison; but because the force thereof
Is feebled by the cold.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: You seem disturbed sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Who'll ever trust devotion, or believe
That any zeal is earnest? I should rather
Have called an eremite hypocrite: or suspected
Th'austerities of an anchorite to be
But for vainglory or a common fame,
Than her appearing goodness. Fury prompts me
To a black act. 'tis well I have no sword.
But may she not survive her first repentance;
Which shame or punishment shall teach her quickly.
Lustful insatiate whore. Could not a husband
Have cooled your blood?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You need no other weapon,She sownes.
Those words have killed me.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Ay me, what have you done sir? help, help.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If it be earnest, cured a wounded fame.
My reputation would have bled a little,
Had she lived longer infamous: her death
May lose the memory of her dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Good gentlewoman she faints. Help, help.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: The cry came from this chamber.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'Sfoot sir, 'tis mistress Cicely, and Cicely mistress. Ha, ha, sir; did you put her to the squeak? I'll put you —

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Hold sirrah.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: Look up my love: ha! What malicious chance
Begets this new prevention of our happiness?
O let our souls together climb the height
Of their eternity; if fate denies
Other enjoying.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: 'Tis my Worthgood's voice.
That Orphean music charms my senses back
from the dark shades of their privation.
Welcome again: I never more will lose thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What are you sir, that seem thus tender of her?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: I give no answer to uncivil questions
With calmer words. And yet I scorn to strike,
Unless I saw some armour for resistance.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: This is my husband brother, far as vows
Can join us, till church-ceremony hath
Confirmed it stronger.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: He your brother sweet?
His pardon first; then leave I may embrace
His worthy love.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis not your compliment
Can win upon me. If your worth deserves
My sister's love (I hope my uncle's care
Hath well examined it) freely enjoy
What you desire: but my opinion is
Scarce settled yet. You seem a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: And am one: that was given me in my birth.
If not, my sword hath purchased it.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: With leave
I would relate the accident to satisfy
Your curious love; which makes you doubt that ill
Never stained a thought in her: and for myself,
My life's untouched by envy.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Gentle sir,
Let my persuasion work upon your temper;
And make it pliable to forgo all jealousy,
And misconstruction. Something is reserved
In mine own knowledge, shall disperse those clouds
That muffle error in their misty rolls;
And makes it blind in all things but in mischief.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If Bellamy be virtuous, she's my sister;
And shall not lose that interest.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Now Cicely,
'Tis time that you disrobe.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: By no means father.
My part's not ended yet.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Please her accept
Th'exchange as my thanks gift; since to her care
And full discretion I must attribute
My safety. Something's now in action,
By her begun from an ingenious practice,
Will make the end more comic.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: But 'twill turn
To a sad tragedy, if I enjoy not
This worthy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: A larger room
Were more convenient. Please you sir the house
Is well accommodated.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: What's more to be expected
Can cross or crown our loves with new events? Exe.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Go your ways and quarrel no more, lest I be stickler with this terrible emblem of a butcher's cruelty. Exit.

div.head: The seventh scene.
div.stage: Enter Changelove, wife; Stitchvveli in a chair asleep.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The effects of drinking, Mr. Changelove: his head should be troubled with something else, were he ruled by me. But he cares not for my counsel, nor me. I could e'en curse mine own kindness, that am ready still to make more of him than he doth of me.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Why do you not then —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What sir? I warrant you mean make him a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: That's a gross construction. Give a friend leave to do you a pleasure, or so. The truth is mistress I love you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You were ever kind Mr. Changelove.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: And would your freeness give me leave t'enjoy
Those sweets, although forbidden, 'twould be a happiness
Above my desire. Be assured my secrecy
Is firm as night and locks.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Secrecy, Mr. Changelove? I would have you know I will be open to all the world. I'll do no more in the dark, then in this very place, were my husband's eyes open.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Here then. He sleeps securely, never dreaming of any foreheads arming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fie Mr. Changelove, you are such a tempter. Pray set hear many a woman would not hold out so long.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Consent then sweet; we'll to it.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Ware horns there.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Mischief, what noise hath woken him?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: An infirmity he hath to talk in's sleep. Nay I assure you he will rise sometimes and do the office of a waking man in his dream, and not know of it in the morning.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Rome for one of the headmen in his parish: a monster of his wife's making.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wicked man; he dreams now that I would make him a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Send it be no counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: And have I ta'en you sir Lancelot? would you be billing with my Guinever?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Help me mistress Stitchwell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Take it patiently sir: his fit will be over presently.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: For this attempt King Arthur doth here degrade thee from a knight of his round table, to be a squire of his wife's body. So conduct me to her bed; where I will beget a race of warriors shall cage thy great turkship again, and restore Constantinople to the emperor.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: You mistake: o. My periwig is not a turban.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Peace follows victory, let us now to rest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, forgive him: I dare undertake he'll be sorry for it when he wakes. If any thing I can may make amends.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Prove his dream true. When the smart's over I shall forget it. Enter tapster.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: A quest of inquiry is sent all the house over to look you mistress. The gentlewoman's maid was in a swoon: they wanted your assistance.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Who wants assistance? who breaks the King's peace? fetch me my constable's staff.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: He'll dream again: had I best stay?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now drunkard, are you recovered yet?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Wife and Mr. Changelove, where's the company?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Gone, being weary of such a sot as you make yourself. Pretend a walk for health and recreation, to be drunk so early? I had done well to have served you in your kind: here were gentlemen enough that would have brought me home; and some not far off that used me kindly, whilst you snorted to fright fleas, and dreamt perhaps some wickedness of me.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Prithee peace sweet wife: I'll mend all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I promise you, you shall never mend me, till you do better yourself.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: I'll buy my pardon for it with a new gown, and a journey into the country next vacation.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You know John I am easy to be wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Will you discharge the reckoning Mr. Changelove?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Not willingly: I do not love it. No revenge upon this dreaming tyrant over unpaid for gallantry? A protection to defraud him is long since provided. What is your reckoning, Robin?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Nine and threepence sir.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: The particulars.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Cakes two shillings. Ale as much. A quart of mortified claret eight pence. Stewed prunes twelve pence.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: They were dear.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Truly, they cost a penny the pound of the one-handed costermonger, out of his wife's fish-basket. A quart of cream, twelvepence.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: That's too excessive.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Not if you consider how many carrier's eggs miscarried in the making of it; and the charge of icing-glass and other ingredients to cremify the sour milk.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: All this is but a noble.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Pray mark me sir, I'll make it more. Twelvepence sugar. You had bread sir.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: And we had drink sir.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: 'Tis granted sir. A pound of sausages, and other things, nine shillings and threepence. Our bar never errs.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: I'll talk with your mistress. You know my meaning Robin. Steals away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O the extortion of Tottenham-court!

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: No matter wife: kind Mr. Changelove will pay for all. Ha! where is he?

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: Gone sir.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Then give me my cloak.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.p: The reckoning first sir.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: How! must tailors pay gallants reckonings?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sure husband, he intends this a satisfaction for his beating.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Have you such tricks? No great matter: 'tis but adding it to his bill in my debt-book, and presently arresting him with a fat martialist. Here sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tapster
sp.l: You're welcome sir. Some profit comes from hence:
I have o'er-reckoned one and twenty-pence. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter George and porter with the trunk, presently after them uncle, servant and tenants.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: A heavy burden I assure you sir.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: That's strange: a light wench, and feathers.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: You say true sir; 'tis enough to break a man's back.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: His mistake hits upon truth. Rest thee porter.
O this plots quaintness: witty luxury,
How it acutes invention, and makes pregnant
Even barren faculties to beget new issues
Of rare conceit. But my credulity
Was rash and sudden. If she hath abused it,
And mocked my hopes of pleasure, what revenge
Can give me satisfaction? Here's the key,
Though late these doubts arise, I greatly long
To have mine eye resolve them. Company,
Forbear a little then, and rest thee porter.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: 'Tis a fair circumstance, and may confirm
My first suspicion. Where found you the horses?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: In the high way near yonder houses. The place is called Tottenham-court.

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p: Our intelligence hath something landlord.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p: The truth is being weary —

sp.speaker: 2 Neig.
sp.p: Old men landlord, old men. Labour agrees worse with us then wrangling with a lean parson that hath a fat benefice.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Pray 'Interrupt him not: forwards neighbour.

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p:
At a house yonder we prevailed to be let in:
where the little time that remained till morning we slept soundly.

sp.speaker: 2 Neig.
sp.p: And dreamt we were in Cranborne church at a drowsy sermon.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: On good neighbour.

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p: Day no sooner peeped, but noise waked us. The house was presently full of gallants with music, and to dancing they went. We asked the reason, they of the house told us 'twas customary for gentlemen to have early revels and rendezvous there. At length we heard one speak of a gentlewoman in a satin gown: which we conceiving to be mistress Bellamy, made haste to London to your son to inform your worship.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: O my cursed fate; they have prevented sure.
My care, by zeal and nature so instructed
To tender her good, that I have not left
Counsel or threats unurged to perfect it.
They are questionless matryed.

sp.speaker: 2 Neig.
sp.p: Might I advise your worship then let them alone till night: when they are in bed together, they are the likelier to be caught napping.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: My nephew's gone abroad too. Is't the custom
Of students that pretend a love to learning
And noble sciences, to make the morning
Their time of recreation? Or have they
Had correspondence, and his friendly aid
Is in the plot! Yond porter may perhaps
Inform us something.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: If these question the porter, I must answer for him.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Good speed friend. Didst see a gentleman and a gentlewoman abroad in the fields?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Betwixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He means the clock: his hearing is surely imperfect.
Didst see a gentlewoman in a satin gown?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a heavy burden: I fetched it from Tottenham-court.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Didst see a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: A gentlewoman in a trunk of feathers! that were very pretty.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: O villain.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A gentlewoman at Tottenham-court!

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I saw many there sir, and one in satin: but they are all upon parting.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: I thank you sir. Come let's hasten. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: What may this be! It hath begotten new jealousies.

div.head: The second scene.
To them Frank.
div.l: And here's new mischief. Hath the devil policy
To prevent ill? There's no avoiding him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis he: h'hath spied me; and his fears deject him.
Sweet constancy, how I could blame the good
Thy kindness means me, that hadst rather lose
Thine own white purity, then stain my credit
With spots time cannot wash out. Doubly happy
Shall I be in enjoying her, and punishing
A treacherous friend.
George, how long have you conversed with the frock-trade?
I thought the smock had been your chief delight.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: The porter waits upon me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With stuffing for your bed.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: A light commodity I bought at Tottenham-court. Didst ever think I should have been so thrifty to buy feathers at the best hand? When I have used them thoroughly, there are suburb upholsters will give me my money again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: methinks they are very heavy.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Let them alone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Have not you stolen mine hosts great brass pot she boiled old marrowbones in, for the fat to make her
cakes with when butter is scarce? Porter you shall carry it along with me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Prithee go back to thy milk maid.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dost thou deride me? Nay then porter up with it, or here's a goud to force you, and let out some of your goat's blood.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Thou dar'st not strike a friend basely.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Friendship is cancelled.
Thou'st broke the league that knit over our outward love:
For in consent of ill love's never solid.
Hadst not abused that love with foul intents:
I would have thanked thy pains, which she contrived
Only for me t'enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Is't even so!
You shall hear from me Frank. Come hither porter,
She hath legs to walk with you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But that I think disgrace a punishment
Worthy the guilt, this instant hour should give
The wrongs thou didst intend a satisfaction.
I must be bold sweet: mine are no porters shoulders.
A coach waits not far off.

div.head: The third scene.
To them Changelove, Stitchwell, wife.
div.p: Lie still a little, here's company.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Let me ruminate.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: I paid the reckoning Mr. Changelove, and am sorry for it, I mean the wrong I did you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: 'Twas no offence: or had it; you have satisfied.
I love the memory of it. 'twill be a story
To greet a ring of friends with: next I meet
Shall have it all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
It may pass indeed for a merry one by a good
fire in winter, which I love dear.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: A good fire mistress Stitchwell is winter's artificial sun, that renews summer within doors. I love it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: With two or three good companions, and a gossip's feast.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: That's very right. Society is the use
Of man's best ornaments. Speech and discourse
Are reasons messengers, that carry errands
From one soul to another. I confess
I love good company.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: 'Tis a good exercise to rise in a frosty morning, and kill birds.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: You say well sir, we that have youthful blood,
That capers in our veins, and swells their concaves
With active warmth, should be enured to hardness.
'Tis healthful, and I love it.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I have it. Do you know these Frank?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mischief, I must prevent them.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: You may if please you, suffer the porter to pass, and stay yourself. Credit is precious: let me enjoy my sport, yours may be preserved. Otherwise your trull and you shall both suffer. I am desperately resolute, and will reveal all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I as desperate. Up with it porter.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Any thing: will you suffer this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Nay then Frank. Draw ▪ and a pass or two.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Help help.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: If he be gone sweet heart, let me out. I am almost stifled. They take him out of the trunk.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whence that voice?

sp.speaker: Short
sp.p: The gentlemen that were in our company! Let us prevent them. Be not afraid wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas I cannot endure such naked weapons.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I beseech ye gentlemen kill me not, I have been sufficiently mortified; and I believe you may smell, the effects of my fear.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Is this the lovely piece, for whose enjoying
I have attempted what by ill success
Makes me ridiculous: yet I swell with laughter
To think how finely she hath gulled us both,
And mocked our easy trust.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray sir how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I think upon that porter's shoulders.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But how into this trunk?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: I'll tell you sir. Bargaining for a little sport with the gentlewoman, whom I thought to be a wanton, she possessed me with scare, (To which cowardice is always apt, and I must acknowledge in myself) that a gentleman (One of you two I take it) had dealt with her for her maidenhead, and that she expected him. He came: and I fearing lust as well as love would brook no rival, made use of this for my safety. Where being heavy headed with ale, I have slept till your noise waked me.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: An excellent conceit; how like you it wife? This gentleman cannot endure the company of women.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I knew before he did but dissemble: that made me so desirous to try him. There was a tub at Tottenham; you I now the success of it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I ever thought mistress Stitchwell that was your own plot; and I love you dear for it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Love me Mr. Changelove? Take heed my husband do not dream of it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: That was her plot too. Now do I see, some women can counterfeit wickedness, as well as many dissemble honesty. Come sir, let you and I drown the memory of our disasters in a cup of sack. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You see gallants what success attends your enterprises.
Henceforth account not every city wife
Wanton, that only loves a merry life.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.l: And here's a double comfort; being wedded,
She's neither false, nor am I jealous headed. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Accursed credulity. Could not those doubts
I shaped my jealousy, preserve my first,
And noble resolution I had I urged it
With greater zeal, she must have forced her reason
To understand m'intention without practice
Of farther trial. Now she's lost for ever;
Though I should with submission and repentance
Beg reconciliation with her thoughts,
(Whose purity cannot endure to mix
With mine that were so foul) she would reject it.
I'll back, and try. Lustful affections hence.
My love's new clothed in virtuous innocence. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Frank we are friends: since we have shared disgrace,
We kill all malice. Henceforth I shall strive
To live more chaste. Lust is a gilded pill,
Which sinful nature doth prescribe desire.
It mocks the sense with pleasure; but at last
The shining outside leaves a bitter taste. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But prithee tell me, what's her condition?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Womanish. She'll cry when she's angry; laugh when she's tickled, and be sick when she cannot have her own will.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I mean her calling.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: She is called Sicily.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Her profession then.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Not very honest, and yet very honest. She cheats all the world that thinks she is wanton: but you may find by the late storeys, that neither your ants nor cousins can keep their legs so close.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Here's money for thee.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
You are as bountiful as a new made knight, that
courts a city widow by attorney for the officers fees.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Prithee tell me how was she born?

sp.speaker: Slip
sp.p: You had b●d ask the midwife.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: This fellow trifles. Is the keeper thy master her own father?

sp.speaker: Slip
sp.p: Should you conjure the devil into her dead mother, he might chance to tell you ●lye.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is she a gentlewoman or not?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: She is ▪ and she is not. She is a gentlewoman as she loves pride: which makes gentlewomen apt to fall; especially those of the waiting form. Then she is no gentlewoman because — because —

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'Tis well you interrupted me, for I had no reason: but sir I will bring her to the bar of your presence, where she may answer for herself, whilst I convert your bounty into wholesome nourishment from a black pot, and have a bout with mine own sweet turnip.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Mine eye ne'er saw with aptness to desire
That beauty could enthrall m'unbounded thoughts
With passionate affection. Yet this piece
Is absolute, and such as cannot choose
But have a glorious mind. Love is a cement
That joins not earthly parts above, but works
Upon th'eternal substance ▪ making one
Of two agreeing souls. Were she born nobly,
(As surely such perfections cannot be
The issue of base parents) so that infamy
Might not succeed, here would I fix my choice.
Besides she's virtuous, and her education
Beseeming greatness: her discourse; pure language;
Judgement, and full behaviour argue it.

div.head: The fifth scene.
To him, Ciceley.
div.l: She's come. How like an angel, as if sent
On some celestial message to the soul
Of a departing saint. White innocence
Is in each look and feature, as all goodness
Had built their mansion in her. Welcome fair one,
I hope my pardon's sealed for thus presuming
On what you might call rudeness .

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: You have shaped
Needless apology to excuse a guilt,
When none appears. I owe much to your virtue
It doth command my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Which are so glorious,
I must admire the actions that express them.
I hope your judgement doth not call it ill,
That my intemperate anger being grounded
On virtuous suspicion, did transport me
Beyond a moderate passion. I am satisfied.
Your innocence hath cleared my jealousy;
Which was I know instruction to my sister,
And th'only working means that kept her safe.
The gentleman she loves I find is worthy:
Though his estate through the improvidence
Of a free minded father, low enough.
My uncle may repair it: she hath hopes
T'inherit all. And trust me did I love
Where I perceived desert, no inequality
Of fortune's blind additions, birth or state,
Should interpose a let to my enjoying.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a noble resolution,
Pure love's a virtue nature only teacheth;
And's born with generous spirits that distinguish
the object truly; slighting those respects
That work on grosser minds.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How she instructs me
In resolution? Fairest I shall use
None other circumstance, or paint a passion
My reason's eye allows: though first my sense
Conveyed the knowledge of your outward form,
And full perfections, which must needs contain
A richer inside. Virtue seldom dwells
But in a glorious frame. I love your goodness:
For that your beauty. In my new born wishes
I have determined you the partner
Of all that's mine. My state's not very mean:
If 'twere, zeal should supply; I'd strive to merit
The free gift of yourself, and in exchange
Return myself.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Sir, I could answer you
With your own words: for I presume your thoughts
Are noble like yourself; unmixed with flattery,
Courtships infection; and the poisonous breath
That many times doth make pure love suspected
Whether it be found or plastered to deceive
Our credulous weakness, till it hath possessed us
With some foul leprosy. Your handmaid yields
To what agrees with honour; if the meanness
Of her condition may presume to call
Her honest credit so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How you do bless me
As suddenly as my desires could shape
A means to work it? Instantly the church
Shall seal the bargain.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Would not you deliberate
Those acts are lasting, and concern the being
Of all your after life?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis heaven's providence
That hath disposed it. Thus I seal my vows

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: And here are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My uncle! what makes he here? new doubts arise.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: See, see; my thoughts were prophecy: both here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You are welcome to Tottenham court uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: But you're ill come cousin. I had thought.
Your judgement had been stronger than to aid
A foolish sister with your fond indulgence
In her undoing. She may hide her face
My rage distracts me, and I know not how
To frame th'induction.

sp.speaker: 1. Neigh.
sp.p: Why sir, this is not mistress Bellamy but another in her clothes.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: How's that knave? hay day wife how came you by these? where

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: I am your niece.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: You my niece?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She's my wife, uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Yet more plots I sure the parson of 〈◊〉 has been here.

sp.speaker: 1. Ten.
sp.p: Indeed I have heard he is a notable joiner.

sp.speaker: 2. Ten.
sp.l: And Tottenham-court ale pays him store of tithe.
It causeth questionless much unlawful coupling.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: Pray where's your sister? I'll not fright her
With many threats, but mildly work her reason
To understand her errors; and prevent
Her ruin with dissuasions. Coss she's lost:
My love and care made useless.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is she married sir?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: Yea; that's my greatest fear, she's passed recovery,
Woman, whate'er you are, you have some hand in't:
These were her clothes.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Let herself satisfy,
If passion hath not made you too uncapable.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Alas mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: Killing spectacle.
Come from his arms: if any force restrain thee
But thine own freeness (Which I most do fear)
I will reveng't with law's extremity.
Come from his arms I say.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Uncle I owe
You many duties. One from nature's precepts;
And moral gratitude for your great love
Instructs me in another: but necessity
In this compels a virtuous disobedience.

sp.speaker: V●c.
sp.l: Girl he's a beggar. He had a prodigal father
That spent all ere he died: his whole estate
Depends but on the love of a rich uncle;
And that's incertain.

sp.speaker: ●ort
sp.l: Pray upbraid me not
With a dead man's misfortune. I have been
A soldier, and perhaps am apt to anger.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Threaten your fill sir, so my niece forsake you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Kind uncle, call not poverty a sin.
Wealth's but the gloss and outside of desert.
And for my sister, since she loves this gentleman,
She hath some portion left her; your estate
Would be a fair addition: but the loves
Of uncles are uncertain. The truth is,
I love this maid: she's but this keeper's daughter;
Yet I would marry her, please her good father
To be consenting.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Blessings unexpected.
If she be willing. She's a poor girl sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She's richer than the Indies.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: Shall mine age
Be cursed to this misfortune. I'll build hospitals:
Where wooden legs and lazy hypocrites
Shall be mine heirs.

sp.speaker: 2 ten.
sp.p: And the devil your executor.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: They scorn my easiness.
I should have raged, and from a furious an
Sent threats, not calm entreaties.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: That would likewise
Have been as useless. I conceive such joy
At these events, they almost have confounded
My preparations to begin the story
Reserved to crown all. First do you embrace
A natural sister.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: Mine own sister, sir,
Supposed to have died an infant!

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: I still thought it
By an instinct.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: This is Cicilia Worthgood,
Whom my wife nursed when both your parents died.
I have been careful of her education
Well as her person; though my love concealed
The knowledge of herself still from herself.
Lest I should lose her: being th'only comfort
I wished from providence: such was the duty
With which I honoured your dead ancestors
That brought me up.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Sir, this concerns not me.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: It doth your nephew, to whose loves embrace
I next commend her, and a portion too.
She shall inherit something that hath been
Stored from my care; nor hath her industry
Wanted a share.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Still let me call you father;
whose love deserves it for my preservation,
And after being.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: What a knot of fortunes
Is here untied. O let me wear you ever
Upon my heart with these. Enter servant hastily.
Mine uncle's servant! What new accident?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: O sir, never was endeavour so tired. But I am glad I have found you. Your uncle's dead, and hath made you his heir.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.p: Ha, ha! is't come about! nay then; are you married niece? if not, about it presently whilst 'tis morning. Thou shalt be mine heir likewise: love him; lie with him; get boys, and any thing now; you have my consent.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And now I owe you duty.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: With what impudence
Shall I apparel my prepared excuse,
To make it pass? What mean so many people?
I am returned to chide your cruel practice,
That mocked my virtue into wicked frailty,
And an abused belief. I am your convert;
And come with more than sorrow, satisfaction.
Let not the memory of my past errors
Pervert your thoughts into a worse opinion
Of my reclaiming, then if ill intents
Had ne'er expressed themselves.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: What means that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: He's one of those that —Whisper.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: If you'll have my maidenhead,
A husband's leave is light.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: As your commodity:
How did you like it sir? Enter host.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: They will abuse me
Into a madness. Farewell virtuous maid,
And bless his bed deserves thee. Here I banish
All after-thoughts of women; but t'admire
the goodness makes them perfect; since such were
Added to be man's only comfort here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Most opportunely widow. I have solicited long; and if you will now consent, let's bear these company.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: Why then to Pancras: each with his loved consort
And make it holiday at Tottenham-court.

div.head: The epilogue by the hostess.
div.l: Again you're welcome. There's no more to pay.
But your kind liking. Tapster take away
If you deny't, as due for such mean cheer;
And say your first paid reckoning was too dear,
I beg it as a bounty. If I win
Your kind commends, 'twill bring more custom in:
When others filled rooms with neglect disdain ye
My little house (With thanks) shall entertain ye.
And if such guests would daily make it shine.
Our poet should no more drink ale but wine.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
